docs.lead_paragraph: ROBERT POWERS was obviously nervous. It was a March morning, Friday the 13th, there was a full moon and he and his friend Joe Beitz were having eye surgery. They arrived at the office of Dr. Robert T. Spector in Stamford for a last minute consultation before heading on a 20-minute ride to White Plains, N.Y., for the operation called Lasik that Mr. Powers hoped would correct his nearsightedness.

headline.main: Under the Laser, Up Close and Personal

docs.abstract: Article describes Lasik, procedure that corrects nearsightedness with lasers, at TLC-White Plains Laser Center in White Plains, NY (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Public anger over the state of managed care has burst into this year's election campaigns as a major issue, up there with perennials like education, crime and Social Security. In speeches and television advertising, Democrats and a few Republicans are seizing on consumer complaints and calling for a sweeping ''patients' bill of rights.'' In at least a score of states, including New York, California, Texas, Florida and North Carolina, candidates in primaries and general elections for governor and Congress typically are promoting access to more doctors, a right to appeal managed care organizations' decisions on restricting care to impartial tribunals, and freedom to sue the organizations for malpractice.

headline.main: Voters' Anger at H.M.O.'s Plays as Hot Political Issue

docs.abstract: Public anger over state of managed care has become hot issue in 1998 election campaigns, with Democrats and few Republicans seizing on consumer complaints and calling for sweeping patients' bill of rights; candidates in primaries and general elections for governor and Congress, in at least score of states, typically are promoting access to more doctors, right to appeal managed care organizations' decisions on restricting care to impartial tribunals, and freedom to sue organizations for malpractice; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your May 14 editorial calling for a crackdown on New York City's cabdrivers fails to recognize the pressures on drivers that contribute to making our streets unsafe and instead accepts Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's unsubstantiated claim that higher fees and fines will relieve the danger caused by reckless cabdrivers.

headline.main: Can the Taxi Drivers Stay on Strike, Please?; Debts Cause Accidents

docs.lead_paragraph: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West at 79th Street. Tomorrow and Sunday, the museum will present programs that focus on the lives of Chinese-Americans. Both days at 1 P.M., ''Honor Bound'' (1996), a documentary about the World War II veterans of the highly decorated 442d Regiment, comprising second-generation Japanese-Americans who fought while their families were forced into internment camps. Tomorrow at 2 P.M. and Sunday at 3:30 P.M., Ruthann Lum McCunn presents a slide lecture on the Chinese-Americans depicted in her new book, ''Chinese American Portraits: Personal Histories 1828-1988.'' Tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. and Sunday at 4 P.M., Margaret Yuen will demonstrate dances of her Chinese heritage, including dances of warriors and goddesses. Free with museum admission. ''Spirits in Steel: The Art of the Kalabari Masquerade,'' an exhibition featuring 13 steel sculptures by Sokari Douglas Camp, drawing on themes from her homeland in Nigeria and 25 Nigerian masks from the museum's collection. On view through Oct. 12. Tonight at 7, Ms. Camp will discuss her work in the context of this exhibition. She will also hold a workshop for high school students tomorrow at 1 P.M. Reservations: (212) 769-5370. Also on display, ''The Nature of Diamonds,'' an exhibition exploring various aspects of the mineral, from its geologic origins to its uses in technology and research. Through Aug. 30. Admission is by timed ticket only. ''Africa: Explorations and Expeditions,'' featuring firsthand accounts of European and American exploration, as depicted in selections from the museum's rare-book collection. Through Sept. 30. Permanent displays include the dinosaur halls and the Imax films ''Cosmic Voyage,'' ''Whales'' and ''Amazon.'' In the Imax Theater on Fridays and Saturdays at 9 P.M., ''Led Zeppelin in 3-D'' and ''Pink Floyd's 'Dark Side of the Moon' '' in 3-D. Tickets: $9. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 A.M. to 5:45 P.M.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 8:45 P.M. Suggested admission: $8; students and the elderly, $6; children 12 and under, $4.50. A combination ticket including museum admission and one film: $12; students and the elderly, $8.50; children 12 and under, $6.50; under 2, free. Information: (212) 769-5100; to buy tickets by phone: (212) 769-5200.

docs.lead_paragraph: A thousand law enforcement officials fanned out across New York City before dawn yesterday and struck what the authorities called a crippling blow to the Latin Kings gang, seizing 94 members and associates, including top leaders, on charges ranging from possessing guns and drugs to conspiring to commit murders. In what officials called one of the largest coordinated raids in the city since the Prohibition era, heavily armed Federal and city agents with search warrants hit gang homes and hideouts across New York at 5 A.M., hauled suspects away in handcuffs and confiscated caches of guns, drugs and other contraband.

headline.main: 94 in Latin Kings Are Arrested Citywide

docs.abstract: 1,000 law enforcement officials fan out across New York City and strike what authorities call crippling blow to Latin Kings gang, seizing 94 members and associates--including gang leader Antonio Fernandez--on charges ranging from possessing guns and drugs to conspiring to commit murders (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Roughly half of the country's state legislatures are currently in session. So what is going on out there? State Net, a Sacramento group that follows bill developments in state capitols, reports that so far this year 69,457 measures have been dropped into the hoppers -- about average -- bringing the total number up for consideration thus far, including those carried over from previous sessions, to 145,824. Just last week another 911 were thrown in.

headline.main: Political Briefing; Hot Issues Keeping State Legislatures

byline.original: By By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr

docs.lead_paragraph: Anti-smoking forces in Congress won an important early round today in the political fight over tobacco legislation. The Senate Finance Committee voted to raise the tax on a pack of cigarettes by $1.50 over the next three years. The price rise would be much higher and swifter than the $1.10 increase over five years in the measure approved last month by the Senate Commerce Committee. The sponsors predicted that the steep price increase would reduce the number of teen-agers who smoke by 60 percent over the next decade.

headline.main: Defiant Senate Panel Votes for Steep Rise in Tobacco Tax

docs.lead_paragraph: Health Care Property Investors Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a portfolio of properties from the Prudential Health Care Plan Inc. for $86 million. The portfolio consists of 36 clinical operations and two undeveloped parcels of land. Health Care Property, based in Newport Beach, Calif., is a real estate investment trust. It has interests in 276 properties in 40 states. Prudential Health Care Plan is a managed care unit of the Newark-based Prudential Insurance Company of America, the nation's largest mutual insurance company. At the end of 1997, the parent had assets of $260 billion.

headline.main: CALIFORNIA REIT TO BUY 38 PROPERTIES FROM PRUDENTIAL

docs.lead_paragraph: Like generations of poor immigrants before him, the Bangladeshi Mamun Masud sought to fulfill the sunny promise of America behind the wheel of a yellow taxi. Each day spent amid Manhattan's potholes and gridlock was a gift to his young daughters, whose lives, he said, ''should be better than mine.'' Mr. Masud and a friend had teamed up in a common arrangement. They leased a taxi medallion from a broker for $685 a week, adding an extra $250 toward the purchase of the cab itself. One man worked a 5 P.M. to 5 A.M. shift, the other 5 A.M. to 5 P.M. Taking but a single day off, they each made about $800 a week, though repair bills for the overburdened vehicle often gnawed into the profit.

headline.main: HAILING DANGER: A special report.; Behind the Wheel: Long Hours and Hard Feelings

docs.abstract: Special report Hailing Danger, on issue of taxi safety in New York City; Mayor Giuliani's proposals to crack down on unsafe taxi drivers prompted drivers to stay home on May 13; there are deeply embedded problems in complicated $1.5 billion industry: unforgiving arithmetic in leasing of taxis and medallions, inadequate scrutiny in hiring of drivers, grueling 12-hour shifts and high turnover in what is now largely an entry-level immigrant industry, likened by some to sweatshop on wheels; photos (L)
